Quantifiers and QP - Other Quantifiers and Degree Words Other quantifiers, like many, much, and few, come in a different position in the nominal phrase showing their narrower . In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in a few sad children or Sue’s many black dogs. Further, these quantifiers can be modified by degree words such as very and so, as in very many dogs or so much waste or very few children.

In the lexicon, mark the degree words which can modify these quantifiers with the features makeDeg modifies_Q. (If any of these degree words are the same as those which can modify an entire nominal phrase, you can simply add the additional feature modifies_Q to the same lexical entry.) Those which can only occur before the quantifier also need to have the feature QP-initial and those which can only occur after the quantifier also need the feature QP-final. Do not enter either feature QP-initial or QP-final on any degree words which can occur on either side.
